advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This man seems not to be so happy being more productive...<br> Note he uses a paper tape puncher to save newspaper articles. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1983 BADGES</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This surprising advert is dated 1982.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD (SEPT. 87)</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is unlikely that this hideous advert helped early sales of the Archimedes.<br> It said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Acorn are proud to announce the fastest micros in the world * The Archimedes high performance Computer Systems * Using a 32 bit RISC chip, Archimedes represents a breakthrough in microprocessing technology allowing a new order of magnitude in power...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Neurons' jogging"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Sorry, you don't play with me"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> END OF LIFE</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the end of 1985, the entire stock of Alphatronic PC and peripherals is sold to brokers which sold them at 25% of the original price.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Yes, it's really him – William Shatner (Captain Kirk).<br> Did they really use VIC-20 in the Enterprise?<br> That would certainly explain a lot of things...<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your computing teacher at home !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert from 'Byte' magazine</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65 </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b> (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b> (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module (K) <b>$149</b> (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system (K) <b>$1895</b> (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5 (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b> (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal (C) <b>$14.50</b> <br> Trek 80 Video game (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1 (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8 (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>

computer.description:
We don't know much about this strange French computer. It was designed by Patrick Jossier, an award winning French designer, to be used as a word processing computer and only few were sold.
This computer was dedicated to word processing (with a 80*25 text resolution), had a 'hidden' CP/M OS launching the text processor at start. Main CPU was Z80/4MHz, the other Z80 was dedicated to keyboard/display, almost like an 'integrated terminal'.
This computer was 100% french made, from hardware to software (except for the OS).
The system pictured here is Logystem Ecritext 2
________
Contributor: Jean-Yves Gaulier
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke professional keyboard with numeric keypad
computer.name: ECRITEXT
